DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to signify whether the scheduled dose of a radiotracer/radioisotope was administered to a patient.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A version of a chemical element that has an unstable nucleus and emits radiation during its decay to a stable form. (online dictionary)_In a clinical setting, the step-by-step plan for how patients are to be treated; for example, the drug or type of radiation therapy that is to be given, the method by which it is to be given, the amount of time between courses, and the total length of treatment._A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time._The act of the dispensing, applying, or tendering of something to another, such as administration of a medicine.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An unstable element that releases radiation as it breaks down. Radioisotopes can be used in imaging tests or as a treatment for cancer.

Concepts.definition: A version of a chemical element that has an unstable nucleus and emits radiation during its decay to a stable form. (online dictionary)

Property.preferredDefinition: A schedule is an ordered list of times at which things are planned to occur.:The amount of medicine taken, or radiation given, at one time.:The act of administration.

Concepts.definition: An ordered list of times at which things are planned to occur.
A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time.
The act of the dispensing, applying, or tendering of something to another, such as administration of a medicine.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

DataElementConcept.origin: ACRIN:American College of Radiology Imaging Network
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 12/11/10 Created for use in PET Imaging Agent CRF module

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The amount of medicine taken, or radiation given, at one time._The act of administration._An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: A category of organic or inorganic substances, elements, and isotopes used in research or for the prevention, diagnosis, and/or treatment of disease states. Includes biologically active substances that are either synthetically manufactured or endogenous substances extracted and processed to be reintroduced into an organism. Chemicals and drugs also include hazardous substances, and naturally occurring or synthetically produced substances required to maintain life.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The amount of medicine taken, or radiation given, at one time.:The act of administration.:An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

Concepts.definition: A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time.
The act of the dispensing, applying, or tendering of something to another, such as administration of a medicine.

An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated for NCI CCR clinical trial
